title: Simone Biles, Steve Jobs, Denzel Washington Among This Year's Medal of Freedom Recipients; Award, to be presented July 7 at White House, is country's highest civilian honor
text:
"These 17 Americans demonstrate the power of possibilities and embody the soul of the nation—hard work, perseverance, and faith," the White House said in a statement Friday. Mr. Biden himself received the Medal of Freedom in 2017, from then-President Barack Obama.

Here, a list of this year's recipients of the prestigious medal, some of whom will be recognized posthumously:

* Simone Biles, the winner of 32 Olympic and World Championship medals in gymnastics, making her the most decorated American gymnast in history

* Sister Simone Campbell, the former executive director of the Catholic social justice organization Network, known for her "Nuns on the Bus" tour

* Dr. Julieta García, the first Hispanic woman to serve as a college president

* Gabrielle Giffords, former U.S. congresswoman (D., Ariz.) and youngest women elected to Arizona's state Senate who became a gun-control advocate after being gravely wounded in a 2011 shooting

* Fred Gray, a lawyer represented both Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks and one of first Black members of the state legislature in Alabama since Reconstruction

* Steve Jobs, co-founder of Apple who died in 2011

* Father Alexander Karloutsos, former vicar general of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America who has counseled several presidents

* Khizr Khan, Constitution Literacy and National Unity Center founder and Gold Star father whose son, Army Capt. Humayun S.M. Khan, was killed in Iraqin 2004

* Sandra Lindsay, a critical-care nurse who was the first American to get a Covid-19 vaccine outside of clinical trials

* John McCain, former U.S. senator (R., Ariz.) and 2008 Republican nominee for president who died in 2018

* Diane Nash, civil rights campaign organizer and founding member of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee

* Megan Rapinoe, Olympic gold medalist in soccer and Women's World Cup winner

* Alan Simpson, Republican former U.S. senator from Wyoming

* Richard Trumka, former president of the AFL-CIO who died in 2021

* Wilma Vaught, among the most decorated women in U.S. military history

* Denzel Washington, Oscar, Golden Globe and Tony award-winning producer, actor and director

* Raúl Yzaguirre, former National Council of La Raza president and chief executive
